full_action: Before visiting someone’s home, the visitor arranges the visit in advance and confirms a suitable time with the host.

GPT-5.2.name: Joseph Attard
GPT-5.2.story:
Joseph was thinking of bringing back a borrowed book, so he opened WhatsApp and typed, “Hi Marlene, I can drop off your book this week. When suits you?”

A few minutes later, a reply popped up: “Thursday after 6 is best. We’ll be home.”

Joseph answered, “Perfect. I’ll come around 6:30, thanks.” On Thursday he left his office in Mrieħel, parked near her street in Paola, and arrived at 6:28. He sent a quick message—“Outside now”—then waited by the gate until he saw Marlene’s porch light flick on.

When she opened the door, Joseph held up the book. “Here it is. Thanks again.”

“Come in,” Marlene said. “We just made tea.”

“Sure, if you’ve got a minute,” Joseph replied, stepping inside only after she moved aside. He kept his bag on his shoulder and followed her to the sitting room.

They talked about weekend plans and the ferry schedule to Gozo. At 7:05 Joseph stood and said, “I’ll let you get back to your evening.”

He waved from the doorway as Marlene closed the door.

non_action: The visitor drops by unannounced and expects the host to receive them immediately without checking whether it is convenient.

GPT-5.2.name: Kurt Mifsud
GPT-5.2.story:
Kurt finished his errands in Valletta and decided to stop by his friend’s place in Gżira. He didn’t call or message; he just walked up, pressed the doorbell, and leaned on the railing. When no one answered right away, he rang again.

The door opened a crack and Bianca appeared, holding her phone to her ear. “Kurt? I’m in the middle of something,” she said, lowering her voice.

Kurt pushed the door wider with his hand. “It’s fine, I’ll just come in,” he said, stepping over the threshold.

Bianca glanced back toward the hallway. “I’m on a call,” she repeated.

“I won’t be long,” Kurt said, already walking toward the living room. “Make me a coffee, yeah? I’m dying. And I need to talk to you about Saturday.”

Bianca’s eyes moved to the open laptop on the table and a stack of papers beside it. She covered the microphone on her phone and said, “I really can’t right now.”

Kurt sat on the sofa and stretched his arms out along the backrest. “Come on, it’s me,” he said, waving her off. “Just five minutes.”

Bianca stayed standing by the door, still holding her phone to her ear.

principled_action: Because the visitor must deliver something urgent, the visitor calls or messages first, explains the reason, and keeps the stop brief and respectful of the host’s schedule.

GPT-5.2.name: Lara Fenech
GPT-5.2.story:
Lara noticed she still had her neighbor’s mail in her bag—an envelope stamped “urgent” with a bank logo. She stopped on the pavement in Żebbuġ and called. “Hi Renald, it’s Lara next door. I got a letter for you by mistake. Can I drop it off now? I’ll be quick.”

Renald’s voice came through. “Yes, thanks. I’m just finishing a meeting at home. Give me five minutes, then ring.”

“Perfect,” Lara said. She waited near the corner, then rang once when her phone showed five minutes past. Renald opened the door, headset still around his neck.

“Sorry to interrupt,” Lara said, holding the envelope out with both hands. “This came to my box. I saw ‘urgent’ and didn’t want it sitting there.”

Renald took it and looked at the front. “Thank you. Really.”

“I’ll let you go,” Lara replied. “No need to invite me in.”

Renald nodded and stepped back. “Appreciate it.”

Lara gave a small wave from the landing, turned, and walked down the stairs without entering further.

Behind her, she heard the door click shut.

surface_action: The visitor schedules the visit, but then arrives far earlier than agreed and acts as if the host should adjust without notice.

GPT-5.2.name: Paul Zammit
GPT-5.2.story:
Paul texted his aunt in Mellieħa: “Can I come by at 5:00 on Sunday to pick up the casserole dish?” She replied, “Yes, 5 is fine.”

On Sunday, Paul finished lunch early and drove up the coast road. At 3:55 he was already outside her building. He rang the bell and said through the intercom, “Hi, I’m here.”

A pause, then his aunt’s voice: “Paul? I thought you said five.”

“Yeah, but I’m nearby,” Paul answered. “It’s easier if you just open. I’ll be quick.”

She buzzed him in. When she opened the door, her sleeves were rolled up and she was holding a mop. “I’m cleaning,” she said.

Paul stepped inside anyway. “Don’t worry, I won’t mind,” he said, walking toward the kitchen. “Just give me the dish and maybe a glass of water.”

His aunt set the mop upright against the wall and wiped her hands on her trousers. “I didn’t set things out yet,” she said.

“It’s fine,” Paul replied, checking his phone. “I can wait here while you finish.”

He sat at the table and tapped his keys on the surface as she moved around the kitchen.

GPT-5.2.story:

Before leaving, he pressed his shirt, buttoned it to the collar point that felt comfortable, and chose a light blazer that still looked tidy. He checked his shoes, wiped a small scuff with a cloth, and put on a simple watch.

Outside, the afternoon heat sat heavy over the street, so he carried a small handkerchief in his pocket. He arrived at the house, greeted relatives at the doorway, and shook hands one by one.

“Bonġu, Carmel,” an aunt said.

“Bonġu,” he replied, leaning in for a cheek-kiss where offered.

When he sat in the living room, he kept his blazer on while people were still arriving, then removed it neatly and folded it over the chair back once the meal began. During photos on the terrace, he stood straight, adjusted his cuffs, and waited until everyone was ready before stepping into frame.

Later, when someone suggested a short walk to the village square, Carmel slipped his blazer back on and smoothed the front with his palms before heading out with the group.

GPT-5.2.story:

At the doorway, the host’s mother stood beside a small table with candles. Tara stepped in without pausing and said, “I didn’t have time to change,” then flopped onto the sofa, feet up on the edge of the cushion.

A few guests looked over and then looked away. The host offered, “Do you want to use the bathroom to freshen up?”

Tara waved a hand. “I’m fine. It’s just clothes,” she said, tugging at her shirt and leaning back.

When someone suggested taking a quick photo together before dinner, Tara stood, pulled her phone out, and said, “Make sure you don’t get my bad side,” laughing loudly. She adjusted her shirt again while people arranged themselves.

At the table, she slid into a chair, drummed her fingers on the placemat, and said, “Is there any air-con? It’s boiling.”

The host’s mother tightened her grip on the serving spoon and set a bowl down without replying.

GPT-5.2.name: Jade Gatt
GPT-5.2.story:

In her hotel room in St Julian’s, she rinsed the blouse in the sink, wrung it gently in a towel, and hung it over a chair near the air conditioner. She wiped her skirt with a damp cloth, brushed her hair back, and used a small pin to keep the blouse neckline sitting higher.

Before leaving, she folded a light scarf and placed it in her bag. At the door of the party, she greeted the host with a smile. “Hi, and thank you for inviting me,” she said. “My luggage is missing, so I did my best with what I have.”

The host nodded and waved her in. Jade kept her scarf ready and, when they moved outside to a breezy terrace, she draped it over her shoulders and smoothed the ends down.

She sat with her back straight, kept her bag tucked beside her chair, and joined a quiet conversation about ferry times and work.

When the photographer asked for a group photo, Jade stepped into place, adjusted her scarf once, and held still until the flash went off.

GPT-5.2.story:

Leon entered, glanced toward the shoe rack, and moved his cap to his other hand so he could slip his shoes off neatly. “Where should I put this?” he asked, nodding at the cap.

“Anywhere,” Andre replied. “Put it on the hook there.”

Leon hung the cap on the wall hook beside Andre’s jacket. In the living room, he greeted the others, shook hands, and sat down when a chair was offered. When Andre’s mother came in with a plate of biscuits, Leon stood slightly as she approached and said, “Thanks,” taking one with his fingers and placing it on his napkin.

Later, when they moved to the balcony to look at the traffic below, Leon grabbed his cap from the hook only after Andre said they were heading out.

GPT-5.2.story:
Kyle arrived at a house in Dingli wearing a wide-brimmed hat and kept it low over his eyes as he rang the bell. The host, Mariella, opened the door and said, “Hi, come in.”

Kyle walked straight in, hat still on. Mariella’s father, sitting in the living room, glanced up and then looked at the hat.

Mariella said, lightly, “You can hang your hat there, if you want.” She pointed to a hook by the door.

Kyle touched the brim and shook his head. “Nah, I’m keeping it,” he said.

Mariella’s father stood and offered his hand. Kyle shook it, still wearing the hat. A few seconds later, Mariella’s mother came from the kitchen and paused when she saw him.

Kyle took a glass and sat on the sofa, hat still on, leaning back with his arm across the cushion.

Mariella’s father sat down again and turned the TV volume down a notch.

GPT-5.2.name: Imran Said
GPT-5.2.story:

“Thank you for inviting me,” Imran replied. “This is for you.”

Daniela took the bag. Imran stepped inside and looked toward the shoes by the door. “Should I remove my shoes here?” he asked.

“Yes, please,” Daniela said.

Imran bent down, untied his laces carefully, and lined his shoes beside the others. He kept his head covering on and greeted Daniela’s parents with a handshake and a small nod. When an older relative approached, Imran stood and said, “Good evening,” then waited for them to sit before he sat again.

GPT-5.2.name: Aaron Bonnici
GPT-5.2.story:

Kevin said, “We usually put them by the door.”

Aaron waved a hand. “It’s fine,” he replied.

When Kevin’s sister came in carrying a tray of drinks, Aaron pointed at the glasses. “Give me that one,” he said, choosing the largest.

Aaron left the door half open behind him and returned with wet hands, flicking water droplets as he walked back.

He carried the hat in his hands rather than tucking it under his arm, careful not to bump anyone. When he stopped to look at a side altar, he stood still with both feet planted and kept the hat down by his waist.

A friend whispered, “Do you want to sit?”

GPT-5.2.name: Fatima Hili
GPT-5.2.story:

surface_action: The visitor removes the hat at the doorway, but then makes joking comments about the church, contradicting the respect the gesture signals.

They stopped by a candle rack. Ben looked at the rows of small flames and said, “At least it smells nice,” then smirked.

GPT-5.2.name: Andre Zammit
